result.title: Objective
result.description: To assist vulnerable developing countries to implement sustainable, risk-based mechanisms for the management and control of shipsâ€™ ballast water and sediments in order to minimize the adverse impacts of aquatic invasive species transferred by ships.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: By the end of the project, all partnering countries can demonstrate significant improvement in legal, policy and institutional structures, with corresponding reduced risk of ballast water borne marine bioinvasions

baseline.comment:
Although the International Convention on Ballast Water Management was adopted in 2004, minimal ratification by developing countries and no legal, policy and institutional framework in place in most of the developing countries.
No regional approaches and strategies developed to address ballast water issues at regional level and very little regional cooperation on this transboundary issue.
No tools and guidelines to support legal, policy and institutional reform process to address ballast water issues and limited or no technical and institutional capacity to address the issue in most of the developing countries

target.comment:
Lead Agency (LA), National Task Force (NTF) and National Ballast Water Management Strategy (NBWMS) in place in 13 Lead Partner Countries (LPC).
3 Partnering Countries (PC) developed draft NBWMS.
All LPCs drafted National Legislation to support compliance monitoring and enforcement and identified a financing strategy to support the national ballast water management program.
All LPCs are proceeding towards ratification of the IMO BWM Convention.
The regional environmental conventions in GloBallast Partnerships (GBP) regions include provisions supporting BWM convention and regional strategies.

actual.comment:
All 15 LPCs have fully functional NTF and identified LAs. 15 LPCs have drafted NBWMS and 11 have officially adopted it. The remaining 4 are on track to adopt it. National interventions to initiate national strategy development in 50 non-LPCs either through GloBallast PCU/RCOs missions to the countries or via twinning between a LPC and a neighbouring PC.
National legislation passed by 3 LPCs (Croatia, Colombia and Nigeria). Draft National Legislation developed by 12 LPCs (Argentina, Chile, Egypt, Nigeria, Ghana, Jordan, Turkey, Jamaica, Panama, Trinidad & Tobago, Venezuela and Yemen). Bahamas have started studying possible revision of existing legislation on marine pollution to include BWM or drafting of new legislation. 14 LPCs have completed national ballast water status assessment. 11 LPCs have drafted national economic assessment and 4 LPCs have progressed well in this activity. 6 LPCs (Croatia, Egypt, Jordan, Nigeria, Trinidad and Tobago and Turkey) have ratified the BWM Convention. Ratification of the BWM Convention is also well underway in Argentina.
2 LPCs received a hands-on training on sampling and analysis of ballast water with on board training on a ship. These trainings were also replicated at the regional level for 7 LPCs (Croatia, Turkey, Nigeria, Ghana, Egypt, Jordan and Yemen), in Turkey, with also the visit of a marine laboratory.
All LPCs have contributed to the Regional Strategy Development process in their respective regions. In 5 regions, the RTF has finalized the Regional Strategy (CPPS, Caspian, PERSGA, MED and WCAR). In the CPPS and MED, the regional strategies have been adopted by the respective regional environmental conventions. MED has an interim ballast water management regime. WCAR and Caspian Regional BWMS were endorsed by the respective regional Convention meetings. SPREP has a fully approved and operational Regional Strategy on marine invasive species in general. Draft regional strategies have been developed in two other non-GBP regions (East Asia and South Asia).

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Learning, evaluation and adaptive management increased

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: No global, regional or national institutional framework to support the objectives of the Project. However, some capacity exists in GloBallast phase 1 countries that could be utilized. Limited global partnerships to support information exchange and capacity building

baseline.comment: No global, regional or national institutional framework to support the objectives of the Project. However, some capacity exists in GloBallast phase 1 countries that could be utilized. Limited global partnerships to support information exchange and capacity building.

target.comment:
Smoothly functioning Project Coordination mechanism, Programme Coordination Unit and monitoring and reporting system in place
Global, Regional and National level steering committees, GEF-UNDP-IMO Executive Committee and specific Task Forces in place to support and advise on project activities and post-project arrangements. Three GPTF meetings, 15 RTF meetings and 65 NTF meetings held during the course of the Project.
Strategic Partnerships developed with two non-GBP regions and five other global and regional institutions to support outreach activities in line with the overall objective of the project
GloBallast outreach and replication by sharing GloBallast experiences and tools through a minimum of 15 international / regional forums and meetings.

actual.comment:
Fully functional three-member Programme Co-ordination Unit at IMO plus one temporary administrative assistant and Project Implementation Plan (PIP) and coordination structure in place.
Regional Coordination Organizations (RCO) in place, agreements extended (CPPS, PERSGA) and functional in all GBP Regions apart from WACAF where the GCLME/IGCC ceased to exist. Here, the GloBallast works with IMO’s Regional Coordinator in Ghana. The new MoU between UNEP and Curacao is being discussed as well as the future MoU between IMO and RAC/REMPEITC.
MoAs for financial arrangements in place with all RCOs. Project Task Forces in place at Global (GPTF), Regional (RTF) and National levels (NTF) to support Project implementation. GloBallast Global Legal Task Force (GLTF) established to support project activities.
As of 30 June 2015, 4 GPTF, 6 ExCom meetings, 18 RTF meetings and at least 65 NTF meetings held.
Strategic Partnerships formalized with four International Organizations (IUCN, IOI, WMU and IMAREST) through Letters of Agreements (LOAs). Strategic Partnership established with EBRD through IMO-EBRD Marine Biosafety Initiative (MBI) for EBRD Regions. Strategic Partnership established on training and awareness raising with the ASCLME Project, with particular focus on knowledge transfer between the two GEF-funded projects. Global Industry Alliance Partnership established with four founding industry partners (Vela, BP, DSME and APL) and additional one member (Keppel).
GloBallast Partnerships outreach and awareness raising through at least 64 global and regional forums.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: BWM Strategies in place, with legal, policy and institutional reforms developed, implemented and sustained at national level

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: At project conclusion, each LPC is implementing an effective program of ballast water management in line with the IMO Convention and any Regional Strategies. During the project, each LPC is sharing the lessons learned with other countries in the region

baseline.comment: Very little attention to the BW issue in GBP regions. No regulations, CME systems or institutional arrangements in LPCs to address the BW issue, due to capacity limitations. Maritime administrations are in place in all LPCs. No regional strategies developed in any of the GBP regions.

target.comment:
Technical and institutional capacity enhanced to implement LPI reforms in LPCs and PCs, with the assistance of guidelines and templates developed by the Project.
National Ballast Water Management Strategies and Institutional arrangements to implement the Strategy in all LPCs
Revised legal structures, improved CME systems and a cadre of trained experts in all LPCs
Enhanced Regional cooperation and sharing of experiences through agreeing a Regional Strategic Action Plan in each GBP region

actual.comment:
GloBallast Introductory BWM Training Package developed in five languages (Arabic, English, French, Spanish and Russian) to support technical and institutional capacity-building. In addition, 4 specialized training packages developed (Operational aspects, Legal, PBBS and CME). 3 of these advanced training packages have been translated into at least 3 UN languages. The CME training package has been updated to include a new chapter on Sampling based on the new guidance developed at IMO and practical training has been delivered for sampling on board ships and analysis in laboratories.
All 15 LPCs have fully functional NTF and identified LAs. 15 LPCs have drafted NBWMS and 11 have officially adopted it. The remaining 4 are on track to adopt it. National interventions to initiate national strategy development in 50 non-LPCs either through GloBallast PCU/RCOs missions to the countries or via twinning between a LPC and a neighbouring PC.
National legislation passed by 3 LPCs (Croatia, Colombia and Nigeria). Draft National Legislation developed by 12 LPCs (Argentina, Chile, Egypt, Nigeria, Ghana, Jordan, Turkey, Jamaica, Panama, Trinidad & Tobago, Venezuela and Yemen). Bahamas have started studying possible revision of existing legislation on marine pollution to include BWM or drafting of new legislation.
14 LPCs have completed national ballast water status assessment. 11 LPCs have drafted national economic assessment and 4 LPCs have progressed well in this activity. 6 LPCs (Croatia, Egypt, Jordan, Nigeria, Trinidad and Tobago and Turkey) have ratified the BWM Convention. Ratification of the BWM Convention is also well underway in Argentina.
2 LPCs received a hands-on training on sampling and analysis of ballast water with on board training on a ship. These trainings were also replicated at the regional level for 7 LPCs (Croatia, Turkey, Nigeria, Ghana, Egypt, Jordan and Yemen), in Turkey, with also the visit of a marine laboratory.
All LPCs have contributed to the Regional Strategy Development process in their respective regions. In 5 regions, the RTF has finalized the Regional Strategy (CPPS, Caspian, PERSGA, MED and WCAR). In the CPPS and MED, the regional strategies have been adopted by the respective regional environmental conventions. MED has an interim ballast water management regime. WCAR and Caspian Regional BWMS were endorsed by the respective regional Convention meetings. SPREP has a fully approved and operational Regional Strategy on marine invasive species in general. Draft regional strategies have been developed in two other non-GBP regions (East Asia and South Asia).

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Knowledge management tools and marine monitoring systems are effectively utilized to expand global public awareness and stakeholder support, improved understanding of ballast water impacts on marine ecology, and enhance maritime sector communications

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Sufficient information is available by the end of the project for LPCs to implement risk-based ballast water management systems. All LMEs and Regional Seas programs globally have raised ballast water management as an important coastal zone concern, with their members taking steps to address the issue. Momentum on GBM is sustained in the GB pilot regions.

baseline.comment: Very limited information available to port and coastal states on the risk of ballast water mediated AIS introductions. There is no centralized information sharing mechanism on ballast water management requirements by various States. Patchy information on existing invasive species in port waters. Limited capacity in undertaking any port baseline surveys to assist with ballast water strategy development

target.comment:
Capacity built in undertaking port biological baseline surveys through six regional training courses leading to collection of enhanced information on port biological baseline in all GBP regions
Architecture for a Global Marine Electronic Information System for Biosecurity (GMEISB) and the System components identified.
GloBallast GMEISB Portal functions as a global information clearing house mechanism with built in electronic discussion forum and Country Profile Databases showing ballast water protocols and strategies in different regions and countries, that is updated on a regular basis by participating countries
Capacity built in various LPCS on marine biosecurity knowledge management, supported through national level GMEISB portals
GloBallast Port Environmental Parameters Database (GPED) updated to include at least 400 ports and the same used by several GEF and non-GEF countries to undertake ballast water risk assessments.

actual.comment:
Four guidance documents (ballast water status assessment, economic impact assessment, national strategy development and model legislation) were developed and have been disseminated to wider stakeholders through GloBallast website. Most of these tools have been translated into Arabic, French, Spanish and Russian.
Protocols for Port Biological Baseline Survey (PBBS) developed and a related training package developed in cooperation with NIWA New Zealand. The Guidance on Port Biological Baseline Surveys (PBBS, GloBallast Monograph 22) has been developed in partnership with IUCN, IOI-SA and NIO and has been published. Regional level PBBS training completed in all six GBP regions, one LPC (Nigeria) and two non-GBP regions (Black Sea and Caspian Sea). Four LPCs (Croatia, Turkey, Jamaica and Ghana) and one Pilot Country (India) allocated significant national resources to conduct port biological baseline surveys in key ports. All regional strategies include the recommendation to perform PBBS. Following the implementation of BWM measures, PBBS can provide an effective means of evaluating the effectiveness of these measures in preventing new NIS introductions. The conduct of PBBS will also prove useful when port surveys have to be carried out for granting exemptions under the BWM Convention.
Translation of the Monograph 21 on Identifying and managing risks from organisms carried in ships’ ballast water, developed in partnership with WMU, in Arabic and Spanish.
Country Profile Database (CPD) developed and pilot tested with two LPCs (Turkey and Croatia). CPD Training provided in one region (MED). CPD populated by four LPCs so far. All countries participating in national or regional seminars or training are now requested to fill in a country profile form and the information provided will help populate the CPD. This information will also avoid discrepancies with the information provided by member States to IMO through GISIS.
Three LPCs (Croatia, Turkey and Venezuela) developed web-portal on ballast water management and five others have country-specific webpages/awareness materials on ballast water issues (Chile, Argentina, Venezuela, Colombia and Panama).
GloBallast Port Environmental Parameters Database (GPED) updated to include at least 400 ports and the same used by several GEF and non-GEF countries to undertake ballast water risk assessments. Developed draft guidelines for risk assessment in partnership with WMU.
Development of a new website and also a new learning portal that includes a free online e-learning course on the operational aspects of BWM.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Public-private partnerships developed to spur the development of cost-effective ballast water technology solutions

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Cost effective technology solutions and testing standards are developed, tested and promoted through a successful partnership with industry

baseline.comment: Private sector involvement is mainly limited to ballast water treatment technology developments and very limited efforts to enabling activities for market transformation and acceptance, and diffusion of technologies within the shipping industry. Very limited communication between private sector and policy makers at local level. Lack of QA/QC standards for facilities that test treatment technologies resulting in resistance from industry to accept technologies. Fragmented R&D efforts and lack of scientific forums to share R&D information.

target.comment: Global Industry Alliance for Marine Biosecurity (GIA) is launched, a GIA Fund Established (formerly referred to as BWM Innovation Fund in the UNDP ProDoc), test facility standards developed, sediment facility options identified and at least 2 global ballast water R&D symposiums/forums held.

actual.comment:
Global Industry Alliance for Marine Biosecurity (GIA) is launched, a GIA Fund Established (formerly referred to as BWM Innovation Fund in the UNDP ProDoc), test facility standards developed, sediment facility options identified and 5 global ballast water R&D symposiums/forums held.
In March 2009, GloBallast formally launched the GIA with financial participation from four major shipping industry leaders (BP Shipping, DSME, APL and Vela Marine International (subsidiary of Saudi Aramco). A GIA Fund (formerly referred to as BWM Innovation Fund) was established with IMO being the fiduciary of the Fund. The starting capital of the Fund was US$200,000, (contributed by the GIA founding partners), currently reaching US$ 350,000. A GIA Industry Task Force (ITF) established and is chaired by GIA member. 8 TF Meetings held to select the projects to be supported by GIA Fund.
GIA initiated the Global Expert Workshop on Port-based Contingency Plan for BWM. The second workshop gathered 23 participants representing expertise from the Shipping Industry, test facilities, Port Operators and Administrators, BWT Research (Academia and NGOs), Technology Developers, and IMO. Thinking that there are alternative means of compliance is a trend that will increase and further to the workshops, papers supporting this idea have been submitted to the IMO.
7 ICBWM (International Conference and Exhibition on BWM, with Singapore). Completed a scientific study on ballast water treatment technology equivalency standards to support alternative ballast water management approaches. Jointly published by GloBallast and GESAMP. Developed an Advanced Training Package on the Operational Aspects of BWM, with significant co-financing from IMO ITCP.
Organized 6 GloBallast test facility standard harmonization workshops and significant progress achieved in development of test facility standards and an MOU between the Test Facilities creating the “GloBal TestNet”. The MoU establishing the GloBal TestNet was signed in October 2013 by representatives of 16 ballast water treatment system testing organizations to facilitate increased standardization and harmonization of test procedures and information exchange. This is considered as a significant milestone which will now accelerate the development of more technical solutions.
Organized a first ever Shipbuilders’ Forum on the BWM Convention (with IMarEST) in Singapore November 2010, a second one in Istanbul, October 2011. The forum was renamed Shipping Industry Forum in Republic of Korea in 2013. GEF intervention through GloBallast played a catalytic role in transforming an entirely new ballast water technology market, now estimated to be worth over US$45 billion in the next 10 to 15 years’ time.
The 3rd GIA Task Force Meeting approved a set of activities planned to be undertaken under the GIA Communication and Awareness Raising for Environmental Sustainability (GIA CARES) programme. As a result and making use of the new developments in information and communication technologies, the GIA has co-financed the conversion of the existing Advanced Training course on BWM and the CME one to an e-learning package, which allows a much wider reach to the shipping industry – and all stakeholders in general. The e-learning package development has been finalized and the brand new GloBallast learning portal was released in April 2015.
A GloBallast-EBRD Marine Biosecurity Initiative (MBI) was launched to assist the private sector in the Bank regions to address ballast water issues and to build capacity among private sector stakeholders. Funding mobilized by EBRD, training managers subcontracted, and two-phase trainings took place in Ukraine, Russian Federation, Turkey and Georgia. EBRD and GloBallast collaborated in the production of a guidance document, poster and presentation to promote the IMO-EBRD Marine Biosafety Initiative amongst other International Financial Institutions.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen institutional and technical capacities for iterative development of comprehensive NAPs in LDCs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of countries sensitised on functional and operational individual, institutional and systemic capacities required to develop and advance medium- to long-term National and sub-national Adaptation Plans and budgets including use of national systems through Ministries of Finance and local government to channel climate adaptation finance

baseline.comment:
Almost all LDCs have finalised and are at various stages of implementation of their urgent and immediate adaptation plans (NAPAs) with each having different levels of capacity to do so and unclear or overlapping mandates of institutions.
Some LDCs have reported on long-term climate scenarios and their impacts under their National Communications with some having also reported on adaptation options and/or technologies as well as plans to integrate climate change adaptation into long-term planning processes.
Some LDCs are advancing sector specific and cross-sectoral adaptation and development processes through low emission-climate resilient development, green economy, environment-poverty mainstreaming and others with limited coordination between these initiatives
Weak institutional planning processes and mechanisms to pull together and build on from achievements realised through the NAPA formulation and implementation process

target.comment: All LDCs have been sensitised on functional and operational individual, institutional and systemic capacities required to develop and advance medium- to long-term National Adaptation Plans

actual.comment: Except for Haiti and Myanmar, all LDCs have been sensitized on functional and operational individual, institutional, and systemic capacities required to develop and advance medium – to long-term NAPs, thanks to the project (regional sensitization workshops delivered by UNEP covered all LDCs; however Haiti and Myanmar representatives were unable to attend).

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Least Developed Countries are capacitated to advance medium- to long-term adaptation planning processes in the context of their national development strategies and budgets

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of country-specific national and subnational finance strategies building on national systems developed to enable countries with processes to move forward with medium- to long-term climate resilient planning and budgeting process including the use of budget markers to track climate adaptation expenditure
Number of countries with institutional arrangements and trained capacities in place to advance towards medium- to long-term climate resilient planning and budgeting at national and subnational levels

baseline.comment:
Almost all LDCs have developed urgent and immediate plans for adaptation and other related climate change strategies and started their implementation with some having coordination mechanisms in place to integrate them into the development process as well as other elements which could be used for medium- to long-term planning
Almost all LDCs report on lack of capacity, data, expertise, institutions and financial resources to undertake medium- to long -term orientated impact assessment and adaptation planning;

target.comment:
By the end of the project at least 12 LDCs requesting support from this initiative have conducted needs assessments, identified inputs required and finalised NAP papers to advance to medium- to long-term adaptation planning processes
By the end of the project at least 12 LDCs requesting support from this initiative have trained capacities and clear institutional mandates in place to move towards adaptation planning processes in the context of their development strategies

actual.comment:
15 requesting countries have received support in the form or NAP training and or stock-taking exercises (including needs assessments) to advance their NAP process: Bangladesh, Benin, Burkina Faso, Cambodia, Comoros, DRC, Djibouti, Gambia, Liberia, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritania, Niger, Tanzania, Senegal.
15 LDCs technically supported by the NAP GSP have designated institutional focal points to advance the NAP process. This is the first step of gaining an institutional mandate which is a more complex process requiring endorsement by political actors at the Minister, Prime Minister or National Climate Change Policy making bodies.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Tools and approaches to support key steps of the National Adaptation Plan process are developed and accessible to all LDCs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of technical tools, detailed methodologies (by sector) available to support medium- to long-term adaptation planning and planning in all key sectors and at national and sectoral levels drawing on skills of both climate experts and public financial management experts
Number of case studies for medium- to long-term adaptation planning and budgeting developed drawing on both climate experts and public financial management experts

baseline.comment:
There exists limited knowledge on VIA among LDCs, it is not organised, well communicated and remains scarcely understood except in academic settings.
Some guides for assessing and designing adaptation exist, but are weak in methods to cost, prioritise and design national programmes covering all key sectors and targets.
Policy guidance for integrating climate change adaptation into national development planning is weak.

target.comment:
By the end of the project, appropriate guides and related resource materials developed and dispersed through workshops and existing knowledge dissemination websites (APAN, ALM),
At least 5 case studies on the impact of the applications of the guides and other resource materials developed

actual.comment: This Outcome is implemented by UNEP. (N/A)

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Exchange of lessons and knowledge through South-South and North-South Cooperation to enhance capacities to formulate and advance the National Adaptation Plan process

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of region-specific knowledge exchange forums conducted focused on formulating and preparing NAPs (UNEP)
Number of partnerships with global and regional knowledge management institutions established to support countries with NAPs (UNDP)

baseline.comment:
Relevant government entities and other stakeholders in LDCs have limited knowledge of available tools and methods to support their effort in advancing to medium- to long-term adaptation planning processes in the context of their development strategies
LDC government entities have limited partnerships with global and regional institutions to implementing urgent and immediate adaptation needs and no partnerships for medium- to long-term adaptation planning.
No communication and outreach strategy for support to medium- to long-term adaptation planning.
No newsletter or other communication tools for support to medium- to long-term adaptation planning in place as yet

target.comment: At least 5 partnerships with global and regional knowledge management institutions established to support countries with NAPs

actual.comment:
This Outcome is jointly implemented by UNEP and UNDP. Under UNDP's target: 6 partnerships have been established for exchange of knowledge through South-South and North-South Cooperation.
Partnership 1: UNDP and UNITAR have teamed up to focus on skills assessment approaches and sharing these with countries. A skills developed approach has been developed and shared with LDCs at the NAP Expo in 2015 in a dedicated session involving Haiti, Madagascar, Djibouti and Timor-Leste. Non-LDCs also participated in this session.
Partnership 2: UNDP and the Global Water Partnership have established a partnership to collaborate to support LDCs and non-LDCs on the NAPS process and the Economics of Adaptation Capacity Building Programme. This partnership has enabled Africa and Asia and North-South exchange at the NAP GSP regional work-shops in Asia, and Anglophone and Francophone Africa.
Partner 3: UNDP, UNITAR and GIZ have established a partnership for rolling out a jointly developed country level NAP training programme which has been jointly developed, and has been consulted with the UNFCCC and the LDC Expert Group. This has been rolled out in several countries as part of the NAP-GSP support and exchange between LDCs on some of the modules has taken place in the LDC Expert Group regional training work-shops.
Partnership 4: UNDP and UNISDR are in a collaborative partnership to integrate Disaster Risk Reduction into Adaptation Planning. The guidelines is being developed through south-south exchange meetings such as a side event at SBI in June 2015 with over 80 participants with over 10 LDCs.
Partnership 5; FAO and UNDP are jointly partnering on integrating the agricultural sectors into the NAPs process. Based on the NAP-GSP initial collaboration, UNDP and FAO are now supporting 8 countries on NAPs through a BMUB supported initiative.
Partnership 6: The NAP-GSP has linked up with the UNDP Adaptation Learning Mechanism to serve as a knowledge management tool featuring support to requesting countries and for the production of a e-newsletter that goes to over 1200 subscribers. The e-newsletter initially issued every month is now issued around key global and regional events related to climate change and is issued 3-4 times in the year.
The NAP-GSP website is operational and an e-intro on NAP support was produced by NAP-GSP and UNITAR. Existing web-based training materials from other partners were explored (for example, webinars on climate smart agriculture from FAO and GIZ’s webinars on insights into National Adaptation Planning, APAN’s knowledge sharing series on NAPs, etc.) and made available as part of the NAP-GSP website and/or disseminated through quarterly newsletters. Full national training material packages for the Regional and National NAP Training Workshops are also available as key knowledge products on the NAP-GSP website.
Newsletters are issued around key global events, and an online database of subscribers now numbers over 2,200. All existing materials in the NAP website have been integrated into NAP Central.
Existing networks and initiatives are widely used as platforms to promote thematic discussions on NAPs: APAN, AAKNET, and UNDP ALM, UNDP ECCA, and SEAN CC. In addition to the above, the NAP-GSP monthly e-newsletters and the NAP-GSP portal regularly feature outcomes and lessons from country missions, promoting South-South knowledge transfer.
Further, the NAP GSP teamed up with the LDC Expert Group in their side events at CoP and held numerous side events at SBI and COP, where NAP GSP showcased best practices and results.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the capacity for effective management and equitable governance of an ecologically representative global network of protected areas

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Results from segmented target group surveys completed by individuals who benefitted from project-enabled capacity building activities (main groups are: protected area professionals, planners and policy-makers)

baseline.comment: 1. No surveys have yet been designed or carried out

target.comment: 1. Analytical results from segmented target group surveys clearly document improved knowledge uptake among project beneficiaries for more effective PA governance, planning and management aligned with quality components of Aichi target 11 and emerging priority issues facing PA systems.

actual.comment: Feedback from all Stream Leaders of the 8 core streams and 4 cross-cutting themes of the World Parks Congress facilitated and collated by the project. The results were used to develop a draft, and consult, on the Promise of Sydney (PoS - the outcome documents of the IUCN World Parks Congress). This process was made possible through the project and the PoS was finalized and presented globally. A planned final survey on implementation of the PoS will be carried out in November 2015, one year after the WPC, to provide a more reflective analysis of results by the PA community, and allow for feedback on the direction of post-WPC project products and interventions.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Number and type of good practice guidelines and training modules developed by the end of the project.

baseline.comment: 2. No good practices guidelines or training modules yet developed in the framework of the project.

target.comment: 2. At least 6 good practices and training modules developed and accessed online by a minimum of 500 individuals.

actual.comment: By June 30th 2015 the Panorama solutions portfolio (www.panorama.solutions) lists over 120 documented PA solutions. Over 100 ‘raw’ stories from protected areas were collated during the WPC in November 2014. A curation process assures that documented case studies are credible and relevant to PA practitioners and policy-makers worldwide. A focus on the core elements of success in each case can be isolated, shared, and collated and analysed. Additionally, the UNDP-led NBSAP Forum ‘Best Practices’ sections visited by at least 500 people (www.nbsapforum.net) . This is also promoted strongly by IUCN GPAP and project team. Training materials were developed and promoted with project support in at least 10 events at the World Parks Congress, including advanced materials and method for PA Governance at site and system levels; applying and developing protected area standards; applying marine protected area categories; marine protected area compliance training; participatory approaches to documenting indigenous and traditional ecological knowledge; climate change and protected areas (http://warnercnr.colostate.edu/climate-change-webinar).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Quality of key knowledge products produced by the project, as independently assessed by project evaluator using scoring (criteria and scale t.b.d. in due course, but may e.g. include technical stringency, usefulness, innovativeness and didactical elements).

baseline.comment: 3. No knowledge products yet developed in the framework of the project.

target.comment: 3. Average and combined scoring applied to the quality of key knowledge products produced by the project achieve at least 60%, as per the scale and criteria defined by the independent evaluator.

actual.comment:
‘Promise of Sydney’ (PoS) WPC Congress output evaluated by all leads of WPC Streams and Themes, as well as other key contributors. http://worldparkscongress.org/about/promise_of_sydney.html
Feedback form built into the ‘panorama’ beta development website www.panorama.solutions collated from October 2014 to June 2015– feedback also collated during the WPC on specific forms and through pax interviews. Over 80% satisfaction; over 20% of users provided full feedback on content, design, objectives. Further evaluation to be applied in latter stages of project once sufficient use / promotion of materials is achieved.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Knowledge uptake on PAs, facilitated by the ‘strategic platform for development & learning’ provided by the World Parks Congress 2014 and through training delivered through PA learning networks enhances and accelerates the implementation of the CBD’s Programme of Work on Protected Areas (PoWPA) and its Strategic Plan for Biodiversity.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 4. Number and type of learning networks identified, engaged, and mobilized to support continued learning on emerging issues highlighted in ongoing training.

baseline.comment: 4. So far, 3 networks have been identified on a preliminary screening (CAFÉ, CFA and REDELAC), but not yet engaged, nor mobilized, to support learning in connection with the project.

target.comment: 4. At least 3 existing or new learning networks are identified, engaged and mobilized to support continued learning on emerging issues.

actual.comment:
During the inception meeting, the three pre-identified networks (CFA, CAFÉ and REDLAC) were merged into one umbrella network represented by the Conservation Finance Alliance (CFA). As such, they represent one of six networks for support under the project, not three. This is because the CFA already included engagement and networking of both CAFÉ and REDLAC, and the similar subject matter of each (conservation finance) would narrow the project focus from the full spectrum of protected areas themes.
So far, networks identified / engaged include:
1. CFA – to convene their network members and associated experts and thought-leaders, initially through the World Parks Congress (events across streams, hosted in a CFA-dedicated pavilion). Initial follow-up on strengthening their network institutional robustness, and driving new parameters for the role of impact / responsible investment into protected areas (ongoing).
2. Healthy Parks, Healthy People (HPHP) network. Events at World Parks Congress secured through co-finance and integrated with support for activities across streams and themes. Follow-up engagement through direct project support for translation and development of best practice guidance of issues arising that are directly relevant to GEF-eligible countries, in particular links between urbanisation, health and protected areas.
3. Protected Area Governance Learning network. An emerging network of PA governance practitioners and policy actors identified using the World Parks Congress as the springboard. Specific members supported to attend events, and a dedicated post-WPC networking event sponsored. Follow-on support for activities in specific GEF-eligible geographies supported and ongoing.
4. Inspiring a New Generation (ING) network – a key theme of youth and re-engagement with nature emerged in the pore-Congress planning and from the activities at the event. Support to an umbrella network of ‘ING’ practitioners is ongoing.
5. International Marine Protected Area Managers network. Several connector events were supported at the WPC, including pre-WPC training events on marine and MPA compliance. An emerging theme from the World Parks Congress was the need to network MPA managers in a more inclusive, accessible manner. Initial support to the IMPANA network to deliver capacity through learning materials is being considered.
6. ‘Panorama’ Global Protected Area Solutions and Standards network. The use of PA Solution case studies as part of a network of learning on protected areas is underway, with three principle components; knowledge management; peer-peer connection and sharing of solutions; incentives and commitments from PA managers and practitioners to improve performance through the use of PA standards and associated tools

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 5. Analysis of the profiles of target groups.

baseline.comment: 5. Target groups yet to be identified and profiled.

target.comment: 5. Results from profiling applied to project target groups indicate a balanced and effective outreach to protected area professionals, planners and policy-makers enabled by the project, including through the learning networks.

actual.comment: Data for overall attendance at the World Parks Congress indicate a very balanced collection of demographics associated with protected areas, with a majority of protected area professionals. Direct support from the project prioritized ‘those who otherwise would not be able to attend’ – especially women and youth from LDCs and under-represented countries from the GEF-eligible portfolio. Support for such candidates was integrated into the planning of each Stream and cross-cutting theme, to enable a) their own prioritization of resources to similar individuals, and b) to ensure that adequate profiling and participation could be afforded these individuals in the context of event and session planning. Some Streams were more pro-active and able to mobilize resources from other sources, and therefore the allocation of support to participants was based on the applicant, rather than a quota for each thematic area. A total of 109 eligible WPC participants were ide notified and supported to attend, with either full or partial support from the project. Other donors aligned their selection to the project priority selection criteria, including UNESCO and African Development Bank. Of these participants, over 50% were women. Every participant played an active role in at least one WPC event or session, training or network gathering.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 6. Use of metrics in PA assessment and reporting across the GEF portfolio

baseline.comment: [exact baseline t.b.d. upon inception]

target.comment: 6. Improved use of metrics in PA assessment and reporting across the GEF portfolio [target t.b.d. in relation to baseline]

actual.comment:
Baseline indicates basic Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT) used in GEF portfolio relating to PAs. Data from METT assessments not comprehensively collated across the portfolio. METT relies heavily on project-duration impacts rather than verified reporting on outcomes. Lessons identified are rarely, systematically encapsulated into learning materials. The inception meeting decided that two avenues should be explored; firstly, better capturing of the ‘building blocks’ for successful interventions into protected areas to allow for a critical mass of case studies / knowledge management that can be directly linked to capacity-building and training initiaitves; secondly, a new standard for protected areas that would build outcomes into the current tools and methodologies for management effectiveness, governance and sound planning for conservation of key values.
UNDP mobilization of an adapted template to contribute ‘Best Practices’ into the www.nbsapforum.net provided an initial group of ‘solutions’ to be identified and apply a basic level of reporting on successful interventions.
The project-supported ‘Panorama’ solutions template, and adaptation of UNDP template, allowed cross-referencing of ‘best practices’ into the panorama platform. The Panorama solutions template is evolving through project and partner support, and could now offer a tiered metric for GEF-portfolio projects.
Additionally, IUCN used the project investigations into metrics for protected area outcomes, led by the joint WCPA-SSC Task Force on biodiversity and protected areas, also the focus of several sessions at the World Parks Congress under Stream 1 on Reaching Conservation Goals.
From this work, and the results of the PA Governance events, a new global standard and assurance process has been applied to 14 sites in GEF-eligible countries as part of developing an IUCN global standard for PA performance.
IUCN, as a new GEF implementing agency (since late 2014), will integrate requirements for using the panorama solutions template and the PA Green List Standard as addittional metrics over and above the current METT requirement, for all PA-related projects.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Global learning and technical content development on key protected area issues are enhanced and contribute to practical solutions to current and emerging challenges worldwide.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 7. Number of best practice guides, user-friendly online tools and e-modules developed to improve the quality and effectiveness of PA systems.

baseline.comment: 7. No best practices or online tools (incl. e-modules) have yet been developed in the framework of the project.

target.comment: 7. At least 3 best practice guides and 6 on-line tools and e-modules developed for technical support and training to improve the quality and effectiveness of protected area systems.

actual.comment: Best practice guidance contributions supported by the project on several ongoing editions, to be finalized in the latter stages of the project. These include protected area outcomes; protected area governance; healthy parks, healthy people; climate change and protected areas; participatory mapping of indigenous and local ecological knowledge. Online tools include the Panorama platform, youth and young professionals learning network; PAs and climate change platform and webinars. Ongoing engagement with practitioners is needed to identify the best translation of World Parks Congress results into on-line learning tools. Much of this will come from the 6 networks engaged and supported, including the CFA.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 8. Number of learners accessing and availing of best practice guidance and resources, including e-modules; overall satisfaction with materials provided.

baseline.comment: 7. No best practices or online tools (incl. e-modules) have yet been developed in the framework of the project – hence no count metrics for access has been established.

target.comment: 8. Approximately 600 key professionals, who would have been identified, and engaged during the exchange and development of country-case studies and best-practice guidance benefit from knowledge products produced with the project’s assistance.

actual.comment: Over 100 specific participants supported for active participation in World Parks Congress events. Over 150 ‘best practices/ panorama solutions’ identified and attributed to a lead proponent professional. Networking on the development of PA Standards has recorded 202 experts involved in specific evaluation and engagement in applying standards to PAs within GEF-eligible countries. NBSAP forum membership continues to rise, with an increment of 298 since 1st July 2014 to June 30th 2015. Full reporting on numbers engaged will form part of final evaluation, but the project is clearly on track with this metric.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 9. Use of a collaborative framework enables the sharing and promotion of best practices, tools, and guidance.

baseline.comment: 9. No collaborative framework has been established for using and sharing best practices, tools, and guidance.

target.comment: 9. A collaborative framework is identified and used to effectively share and promote best practices, tools and guidance.

actual.comment:
The ‘Panorama’ protected area solutions template designed for use by the project and partners to capture the practice and policy case studies and stories, and their component building blocks of success, has been adopted by a number of partners including GIZ, UNEP and GRID-Arendal through the Blue Solutions partnership; by Ecotrust and the Resilience Exchange Network; by Coalition Wild, Blue Ventures, WWF Tiger Programme; The Coral Triangle Initiative; the Micronesia Conservation Trust and Micronesia Challenge Steering Committee; as well as IUCN programmes (marine, forests, SOS and Tiger granting mechanisms). The framework will also be included in IUCN’s portfolio of GEF projects relating to protected areas.
A version of the template is used by UNDP to capture ‘best practices’ on the NBSAP Forum.
Work is ongoing to refine the template, especially to combine ‘harvest’ of data and results for knowledge management with an active networking tool for practitioners to share and reflect on their experience.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 10. User surveys designed to focus on the utility and quality of shared best practices and case studies.

baseline.comment: 10. No user-surveys have yet been designed.

target.comment: 10. Results from user surveys demonstrate the utility and quality of shared best practices and case studies.

actual.comment: User surveys are still under development / yet to be fully analysed as project is still ongoing. However, for the panorama, user surveys have informed product and portal development based on feedback on quality and user access. Specific user feedback form prominent on interim Panorama Solutions portal promoted at the World Parks Congress, with over 50 direct user responses sourced from the site as of 30th June 2015.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Protected areas assume a more prominent role and position within the development policy, economic strategies and human well-being respective agendas

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 11. Project commitments in at least 5 countries enable integration of PAs into national land-use planning frameworks.

baseline.comment: 11. Countries are preparing for the Parks Congress, but have not yet defined their policy commitments, nor their follow-up actions.

target.comment: 11. Initiatives underway in at least 5 countries to integrate PAs into national/ frameworks and sectoral development plans.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 11a. [as above]

baseline.comment: 11a. [as above]

target.comment: 11a. Recommendations on PA-related policy issues are developed from deliberations at IUCN WPC.

actual.comment: The Promise of Sydney (PoS) document is a complete summary of recommendations related to PA policy and practice emerging from the substance of all streams and cross-cutting themes, and related commitments by all partners, including Governments and international agencies / organisations. The PoS was fully supported by the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 11b. [as above]

baseline.comment: 11b. [as above]

target.comment: 11b. Key recommendations on emerging issues relevant to mainstreaming PAs in national development plans and implementation of Aichi targets are promoted at CBD COPs and other international policy arenas.

actual.comment:
The key elements of the PoS will be carried forward to three upcoming events: UNFCCC Paris December 2015; IUCN WCC September 2016; and CBD COP Mexico, October 2016.
Planning is underway for each. For UNFCCC Paris 2015, three to five African delegates will be supported to present PA and climate change solutions from various regions in sahel / sub-saharan regions.
For WCC and various lead-in events to CBD COP in Mexico, specific activities will be evaluated in Q315 through to Q116.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 11c. [as above]

baseline.comment: 11c. [as above]

target.comment: 11c. Follow-up action plans to promote adoption of protected areas as tools for implementation of other international agreements (e.g. follow up to post 2015 Hyogo Framework of Action for Disaster Risk Reduction )

actual.comment: Elements of project support contributed to the Sendai framework for Disaster Risk Reduction. In Q315 project elements related to PAs and DRR will be incorporated into implementation framework for the Sendai+10 agreement.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Promote the environmentally sound management (ESM) of two sources of potential lead poisoning in the selected countries in Asia, lead in paint and used lead acid batteries (ULABs), in ways that minimize significant adverse effects on human health and the environment

actual.comment: While the project document has not yet been signed by the Government of the Philippines, Blacksmith Institute has begun laying the groundwork for a successful project, beginning its focus in Indonesia. To date, toxic sites have been identified and assessed, research has begun to document the Used Lead Acid Battery (ULAB) Supply Chain in the Jakarta area, the Inception Workshop was held in Jakarta, and a training was conducted in the use of the International Lead Management Center's (ILMC) benchmarking assessment tool.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Scope of pollution and human health exposure risks due to current practices in ULAB recycling/ smelting evaluated and better understood by government agencies and other stakeholders

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of ULAB sites added to inventory (including no. of people impacted)

baseline.comment: Toxic Sites Identification Program database has identified ~100 ULAB lead contaminated sites globally, more than half of which are in Asia.

target.comment: At least 150 lead contaminated sites from ULAB recycling/smelting assessed.

actual.comment:
In this reporting period, 53 lead-contaminated sites have been assessed and confirmed to be of great health risk to local populations in the two project countries, of which:
27 sites were in Indonesia and 26 sites were in the Philippines.
An additional 20 sites were assessed and require further study.
Finally, 4 sites in Indonesia were assessed and determined to be low-risk, not primarily lead-contaminated, or not of serious health concern

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Reports on scope and impacts of ULAB recycling globally and in selected project countries available

baseline.comment: Toxic Sites Identification Program database has identified ~100 ULAB lead contaminated sites globally, more than half of which are in Asia.

target.comment: Reports on scope and impacts of ULAB recycling globally and in selected project countries prepared.

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed by the government of the Philippines before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: List of priority ULAB sites for intervention in each project country available,

baseline.comment: Toxic Sites Identification Program database has identified ~100 ULAB lead contaminated sites globally, more than half of which are in Asia.

target.comment: List of priority ULAB sites for intervention in each project country prepared.

actual.comment: The TSIP database contains prioritized list of sites in each country. Additionally in Indonesia, the team has consulted with the Ministry of Environment and identified 4 priority sites for ULAB interventions over the next 5 years. The team has visited those 4 sites and prioritized one site for the remediation efforts under the GEF project.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Scope of environmental health risk from lead in paint in residential homes is assessed in one urban area in the selected countries, as a model for Asia,

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Report and scientific paper on the environmental health risk from lead in paint available

baseline.comment: Lead in paint sites are not currently recorded in the Toxic Sites Identification Program database.

target.comment: An urban residential study on environmental health risk from lead in paint conducted.

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of agencies/stakeholders with whom the report is shared.

baseline.comment: Understanding of the scope of human health impact from lead in paint not well understood in Asia.

target.comment: At least one scientific paper and report produced on environmental health risks from lead in pain in an urban residential area in Asia drafted

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: ULAB supply chain assessment is completed for the Greater Jakarta region of Indonesia, as a model for Asia, and enhances government, industry and other stakeholder understanding of the economic/livelihood implications, challenges and opportunities for safe management of ULABS in the region.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Report on the results of the ULAB supply chain. Assessment of Greater Jakarta available.

baseline.comment: Dynamics of supply chains for ULABs, especially the informal sector, not well understood.

target.comment: Clear understanding of the dynamics of the supply chain of ULABs in the Greater Jakarta region.

actual.comment: An initial assessment of the ULAB supply chain in the Greater Jakarta region has been completed but the report and presentation have not yet been developed. The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of agencies/stakeholders with whom the report is shared.

baseline.comment: Basel ULAB Technical Guidelines do not incorporate the informal sector/livelihoods issues.

target.comment: Report prepared and shared with each project country.

actual.comment:
Basel guidelines are under review currently by a working group established by the Basel Secretariat. The guidelines are expected to be amended in the fall of 2015.
The Blacksmith Institute Technical Advisory Board (TAB) will review these revised guidelines and provide feedback to the secretariat as well as making country-specific recommendations to the governments that will support this outcome.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Recommendations regarding feasible steps and solutions to mitigate risks from lead contamination and to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recovery, recycling and smelting practices have been drafted.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of functioning multi-stakeholder workgroups established.

baseline.comment: Regulations related to active lead emissions for lead smelters/ recyclers exist, but often are either not enforced or not strictly enforced.

target.comment: Multistakeholder working group established.

actual.comment: As part of the Inception Workshop preparations, a Multistakeholder working group was established in Indonesia consisting of government ministries, industry representatives, small-scale business representatives, and a local lead advocacy community organization. It is anticipated that additional community, advocacy, and NGO groups will be represented as the project grows. The initial meeting of the group was held June 30, 2014.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of reports available which present national recommendations for ULAB and lead in paint action.

baseline.comment: Regulations related to lead in paint exist or are in draft in Philippines, but not Indonesia.

target.comment: Governments, industry and other stakeholders more aware of risks posed by unsafe ULAB recycling and lead in paint.

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: List of recommendations for improvements to the Basel Technical Guidelines for ULABs submitted to the Basel Secretariat.

baseline.comment: There are no country-level plans in the selected project countries for phasing out lead in paint or unsafe ULAB practices, especially in the informal sector.

target.comment: Recommendations and national action plans for phasing out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recovery, recycling and smelting practices drafted.

actual.comment: Blacksmith Technical Advisory Board has begun discussions regarding recommendations for Indonesia. the Basel guidelines will be edited by a working groups within the Basel Secretariat in Fall 2015, further recommendations will be developed by Blacksmith after the Basel guidelines themselves are revised.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of national action plans drafted.

target.comment: Project reports approved.

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: One draft national policy/strategy/regulation or plan includes a reference to lead.

target.comment: One draft national policy/strategy/regulation or plan influenced to include a reference to lead.

actual.comment: Ongoing coordination occurring with Government of Indonesia. The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Local capacity built in the selected project countries to implement the recommended actions to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recovery, recycling and smelting practices,

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 4 ILMC benchmarking and other training workshops/webinars held.

baseline.comment: Lack of capacity, knowledge, awareness, expertise and funding are hindering action to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recycling/ smelting practices.

target.comment: Technical assistance provided to industry and government agencies by ILMC

actual.comment: Training completed in Indonesia in August 2014 with approximately 150 attendees from Indonesian government including Ministry of Environment, Forestry, and Natural Resources, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Trade and Industry, and local government as well as local community members, civil society organizations, media, UNDP Thailand, UNEP, and the private sector

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 60 individuals trained.

baseline.comment: Lack of capacity, knowledge, awareness, expertise and funding are hindering action to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recycling/ smelting practices.

target.comment: Benchmarking Assessment Tool workshops and other trainings conducted in each project country.

actual.comment: A 5 hour BAT training was completed in August 2014 in Indonesia with 32 representatives from government and industry.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of ULAB smelter site inspections completed;

baseline.comment: Lack of capacity, knowledge, awareness, expertise and funding are hindering action to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recycling/ smelting practices

target.comment: Government capacity built to implement actions and conduct lead remediation

actual.comment: 2 detailed Smelter reviews completed in Indonesia and 3 in The Philippines in September 2014- findings and assessment reports have been included in International Lead Management Center (ILMC) report.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: List available of companies interested to improve practices.

baseline.comment: Lack of capacity, knowledge, awareness, expertise and funding are hindering action to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recycling/ smelting practices.

target.comment: List of companies interested to improve practices prepared.

actual.comment: Approximately 20 companies identified in Indonesia, see attendees list from Inception Workshop held in August 2014

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: One pilot remediation project completed.

baseline.comment: Lack of capacity, knowledge, awareness, expertise and funding are hindering action to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recycling/ smelting practices.

target.comment:
At least one pilot lead remediation project conducted.
Exposure risk to lead at pilot remediation site reduced.

actual.comment: Remediation site identified for Indonesia - Cinangka, Bogor Regency

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Measurable reduction in lead exposure risk at pilot remediation site.

baseline.comment: Lack of capacity, knowledge, awareness, expertise and funding are hindering action to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recycling/ smelting practices.

target.comment: Exposure risk to lead at pilot remediation site reduced.

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of backyard ULAB recyclers

baseline.comment: Lack of capacity, knowledge, awareness, expertise and funding are hindering action to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recycling/ smelting practices.

target.comment: # of recyclers trained TBD, baseline and end of training surveys show awareness improvement

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

result.title: Outcome 6
result.description: Lessons learned and best practices for phasing out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recycling/smelting practices are shared with governments, industry and relevant stakeholders in each selected country, as well as regionally.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Two national project workshops held per country

baseline.comment: No ULAB supply chain and urban health risk assessment and exist or have been shared in the selected project countries.

target.comment: Results, best practices and lessons-learned have been shared through workshops and meetings at the national, regional and international level.

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: One regional project meeting held.

baseline.comment: Best practices from USA and Europe, including the Basel Technical Guidelines for ESM of Lead are available to be shared.

target.comment: Project mid-term and final reports available.

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: No of times project results are presented at international/regional events.

baseline.comment: No monitoring and evaluation documents in baseline situation

target.comment: Audit and independent project evaluation reports available

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers.

baseline.comment: Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during project implementation.

target.comment: 4 Quarterly Operational Reports submitted to UNDP each year

actual.comment: The Project Document has not yet been signed. This is the first report being submitted to UNDP.

target.comment: 1 annual APR/PIR submitted to UNDP each year.

actual.comment: draft submitted July 2015

target.comment: 1 Mid-term project review. M&E results and insights are applied to provide feedback to the project coordination process.

actual.comment: Planned for mid-way through the project. The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities and documentation.

target.comment: 1 Final evaluation

actual.comment: Planned for 3 months prior to project closure. The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities and documentation.

target.comment: MTE and FE must include a lessons learned section and a strategy for dissemination of project results.

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities and documentation.

target.comment: Lessons learned and best practices are accumulated, summarized and replicated at the country level.

actual.comment: The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed before beginning project activities and documentation.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To enable eligible countries in need of assistance to undertake critical actions in response to the Programme of Work on Protected Areas that complement, but will not be addressed by, other national programs and projects, including those supported by the GEF, by other official donors, and by international NGOs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
13 Priority Areas for PoWPA Supported
- assessed protected-area capacity needs and established capacity building programmes

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 8 out of 47 countries assessed protected-area capacity and established capacity building programmes

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: - concrete steps taken to identify and put in place positive incentives that support the maintenance of protected areas and the involvement of indigenous and local communities and stakeholders in conservation

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 5 out of 47 countries took concrete steps to identify and put in place positive incentives that support the maintenaince of protected areas and the involvement of indigenous and local communities and stakeholders in conservation

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: - concrete steps taken to mitigate and remove perverse sectoral policy incentives which undermine protected areas.

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 2 out of 47 countries took concrete steps to mitigate and remove perverse secotoral policy incentives which undermine protected areas

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: - concrete steps to promote a broad set of protected areas governance types taken

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 18 out of 47 countries took concrete steps to promote a broad set of protected areas governance types

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: - developed and established long term monitoring systems for the outcomes achieved through protected area systems in relation to the PoWPA

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 6 out of 47 countries developed and established long term monitoring systems for the outcomes achieved through protected area systems in relation to the PoWPA

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: - gaps in national protected area system coverage identified and immediate interim measures to address these taken

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 22 out of 47 countries have identified gaps in national protected area system coverage and have taken immediate interim measures to address the gaps

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: the contributions of protected areas to economy and culture and the achievement of the MDGâ€™s assessed

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 12 out of 47 countries have assessed the contributions of protected areas to economy and culture and the achievement of the MDGs

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: - total protected area financial needs and gaps assessed, and options for addressing them identified

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 8 out of 47 countries assessed protected-area capacity and established capacity building programmes

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: legal and institutional gaps and barriers impeding the effective establishment and management of protected areas assessed

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 16 out of 47 countries assessed legal and institutional gaps and barriers impeding effective establishment and management of protected areas

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: lessons learned on integration of protected areas into broader plans and strategies evaluated.

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 4 out of 47 countries evaluated lessons learned on integration of protected areas into broader plans and strategies

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description: - national-level reviews of protected areas governance types undertaken

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 10 out of 47 countries undertook national-level reviews of protected areas governance types

indicator.title: Indicator 12
indicator.description: - targets and indicators for protected areas delineated

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 6 out of 47 countries delineated targets and indicators for protected areas within the project, although as a result of support to CBD workshops, at least 35 countries of 47 have developed specific protected area targets and indicators within the NBSAP revision process.

indicator.title: Indicator 13
indicator.description: - methods, standards and criteria for evaluating the effectiveness of protected areas management and governance adopted.

target.comment: At least 35 countries (in total for all 13 indicators) undertake critical action on PoWPA

actual.comment: 8 out of 47 countries adopted methods, standards and criteria for evaluating the effectiveness of protected areas management and governance

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Eligible countries receive direct support for undertaking critical actions under the Programme of Work on Protected Areas

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Average time lag between application and award receipt (average time for GEF project approval)

baseline.comment: 3 years

target.comment: Within 3 months

actual.comment: Does not apply in this reporting period, since all grants were disbursed

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of approved country funding proposals

target.comment: 10 per year (Years 1-3)

actual.comment: No new applications; approved applications for the project remains at 57, distributed across 47 countries.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: LDCs and SIDS are not disadvantaged by limited capacity in receiving direct support to undertake critical actions.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of funding awards to LDCs and SIDS (in percent of total funding awards given to LCDs and SIDS)

target.comment: At least 50% of total funding awards are awarded to LDCs and SIDS

actual.comment: 72% (34 out of 47 countries)

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Successful approaches to taking critical action on the PoW and lessons learned about project implementation disseminated and applied by countries

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of funding proposals using lessons from project implementation in other countries (in percent of total new proposals that contain references to experiences of previous projects)

target.comment: At least 50% of new proposals in Year 2 and 3 contain references to experiences of previous projects

actual.comment: 80.95% of proposals learned from previous proposals - as per 2009 reporting.

iati-activity.title: HCFC PhaseOut
iati-activity.description: Compliance with the accelerated Montreal Protocol Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFC) phase-out requirements through stabilization and progressive reduction of HCFC consumption achieved
