indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1a. Russian language resource materials on HCFC control options prepared 1b. Awareness training for decision-makers on legislative and regulatory actions accomplished 1c. Regional networking on the country in the region is supported 2a. Russian language resource documentation 2b. Awareness raising activities 2c. Regional networking 3a. Training of Trainers (enforcement) 3b. Training of Trainers (refrigeration) 3c. Participation in the informal Prior Informed Consent Network 4. Preparation of Russian language training manuals and information materials 5a. Regional networking 5b. Participation in the informal Prior Informed Consent Network 6a. Promotion of Information exchange mechanisms 6b. Facilitation of regional dialogue 6c. Preparation of Russian language information materials

baseline.comment: 1. Key stakeholders generally have limited awareness of the issue or actions required on the higher or technical level to address HCFC phase-out; 2. Decision-makers from enforcement department (Environment Protection, Customs) have limited knowledge and lack practical skills on the regulatory approaches to effectively control HCFC related challenges 3. Limited number or lack of trained trainers on enforcement and best refrigeration aspects 4. Required materials in Russian or local languages, on HCFC control options, Customs enforcement approaches and methodologies, refrigeration sector capacity building, energy-efficiency, alternative technologies and their application, illegal trade and PIC, technician certification and ODS waste management related issues are limited in availability or absent 5. Regional networking with other partner countries in the region is lacking which prevents information and experience exchange 6. Cooperation between non-Article 5 countries on effective action standards is minimal or absent

target.comment: • Project meeting and Project Board Meeting organized • Project Manager (50%) recruited, on board and trained • Key document of Customs Training manual translated into Russian • Other adapted documents developed in 2014 translated, laid out and published electronically • Two (2) missions conducted by the International Consultant on HCFC legislation and customs to Uzbekistan and One (1) in Ukraine • Road-map on HCFC legislation developed for tracking progress in four (4) countries in an harmonised manner • Joint regional Training of Trainers organized for refrigeration technician specialists from all four participating countries and certification obtained by all technicians as an outcome of the training • Four (4) delegations to participate in the Regional ozone network meetings organized by UNEP for Europe and Central Asia in Armenia • Four (4) delegations to participate in the Thematic meeting on HPMPs in October 2015 • Awareness-raising of policymakers conducted through targeted missions of the international consultant on HCFC legislation, in support of the activities conducted by the national teams on a daily basis with partner ministries • International expert retained on ODS disposal in the participating countries • One specific publication on RAC developed for the region and specifically the four participating countries

actual.comment: • Project meeting and Project Board Meeting organized • Project Manager (50%) recruited and started working as of October 2015 • Two (2) missions conducted by the International Consultant on HCFC legislation and customs to Uzbekistan and One (1) in Ukraine • Road-map on HCFC legislation developed for tracking progress in four (4) countries in an harmonised manner • Joint regional Training of Trainers for fourteen (14) refrigeration technician specialists from all four participating countries successfully completed with all participants receiving EU certification in September 2015 • Four (4) delegations participated in the Regional ozone network meetings organized by UNEP for Europe and Central Asia in Armenia • Four (4) delegations participated in the Thematic meeting on HPMPs in October 2015 • Awareness-raising of policymakers conducted through targeted missions of the international consultant on HCFC legislation, in support of the activities conducted by the national teams on a daily basis with partner ministries

indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment: Romania has an ODA legal framework in place with sectorial priorities and geographical areas already established. Nevertheless, Romania should also develop a clear vision on its substantive contribution to global development cooperation and clear niches to position itself on the development cooperation space. 1. No high-profile event on key policy topics has been hosted by Romania during the last 5 years 2. Low number of theme-, region- or country- focused reports/policy papers developed by Romania 3. No communication and visibility strategy in place 4. Limited ODA management capacity and lack of specialized human resources in the field 5. No Mobility Fund or similar rapid response financing instrument has been used before 6. Recent experience demonstrated that Romania, as other new European Union (EU) member countries, has a unique service offering for developing countries on the paths of democratic and market reform to countries in Eastern Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. Few similar events already implemented by the Country Office.

Number of new linkages facilitated among trade and business support institutions in the region. 2.3 Increased export volume achieved at companies receiving support services. 3.1. Number of cooperation channels facilitated 3.2. Percentage increase in production and sales at targeted clients in supported value chains, one year after having received support. 3.3. Number of subsectors in which eco-sustainable business models are developed and readied for scaling up. 3.4. Number of national agro-processors linked to regional and international trade platforms. 4.1 Number of economic zones benefited from capacity building support.

baseline.comment: 1.1. No up-to-date research data available on trade opportunities in Fergana valley. 1.2. No up-to-date policy papers prepared with participation of stakeholders from concerned countries and ensuring buy-in from respective governments. 2.1. Lack of awareness among potential clients about existing and new trade opportunities. 2.2. Lack of regional cooperation among trade promotion institutions. 2.3. Lack of knowledge about more efficient agricultural production methods. 3.1. Regular cooperation channels for SMEs in the region not available. 3.2. Intensifying competition in traditional subsectors with very slow diversification into higher-value added production and to non-traditional subsectors. 3.3. Systematic survey on eco-sustainable business models not conducted yet. 3.4. Most agro-processors are not linked yet to trade platforms. 4.1 Experience with running special economic zones is limited;

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1.1 Number of national trade related policy documents adjusted to WTO (and in case of relevance, CU) requirements. 1.2. Number of priorities from WTO post-accession plan implemented. 1.3. Number of national and Oblasts’ strategic trade related policy documents developed. 1.4. Number of regular coordination meetings among Central Asiancountries on cross-border issues.
2.1. Trade/Export Capacity Development Programme (TCDP) established at national and Oblast level 2.2. Number of Trade Promotion Centers (TPC) established with improved capacity on providing services to clients. 2.3. Number of SMEs/entrepreneurs served by National and Oblasts TPCs. 2.4. Number of Business Associations providing improved capacity on advocacy and providing services to members. 2.5. Served TPC clients are satisfied and % of paying for the services. 2.7. Number of SMEs having participated at regional and international exhibitions increased their export turnover in percentage.
3.1.1. Number of innovative green business ideas supported through the Business Challenge Fund (BCF). 3.1.2. Number of decent jobs created. Percentage of jobs created for women. 3.1.3. Number of female headed enterprises supported by the BCF. 3.1.4. Percentage of productivity increase at supported businesses one year after start of support. 3.1.5. Percentage of export volume increased at companies receiving BCF services (including female headed companies).
3.2.1. Number of additional Oblasts covered by AIMS. 3.2.2. Number of additional (gender-differentiated) subscribers stating to have benefited from AIMS. 3.2.3. Number of demand-oriented new services of AIMS and mobile phone applications developed. 3.2.4. Percentage of spatial coverage of Tajikistan by Agricultural Map and Trade Platform of AIMS. 3.2.5. Number of Marketing Information Systems in CA region interlinked. 3.2.6. Number of national agro-processors linked to regional and international trade platforms.

baseline.comment:
1.1. Tajikistan joined WTO in March 2013, requiring means to improve implementation of WTO post-accession plan. 1.2. Trade Road Map Action Matrix not developed yet. 1.3. Trade related strategic documents at national and oblast level (except Sughd region) not available yet. 1.4. Governmental and non-governmental actors have irregular coordination meetings on cross-border issues.
2.1 Trade/Export Capacity Development Programme (TCDP) for entrepreneurs do not exist at the national and Oblast level. 2.2 Trade Promotion Centers do not exist at the national or oblasts level (except of Sughd region). 2.3 Entrepreneurs at the national and oblast level are without access to advisory and training services on trade related issues. 2.4 Capacity of Business Associations on advocacy and providing services is weak. 2.5 No data. 2.7 Due to limited access to foreign and new markets, SMEs have low export turnover.
3.1.1. Commercial loans available only with high interest. 3.1.2. High level (51%) of female unemployment. 3.1.3. In TJK, only 16% of enterprises are headed by women. 3.1.4. Low level of business productivity. 3.1.5. Low export volume of agro-processing companies.
3.2.1. Coverage of the Agriculture Information and Marketing System (AIMS) limited to the Sughd Oblast. 3.2.2. More than 6,000 AIMS users in Sughd Oblast. 3.2.3. Current services provided by AIMS is covering the country’s needs only partially. 3.2.4. Spatial of coverage of A

target.comment: 1.1. At least 2 national trade policy document adjusted in 2015. 1.2. At least 2 priority in 2015. 1.3. At least 1 document developed in 2015. 1.4. At least 2 coordination meetings conducted. 2.1.TCDP established at 2 oblasts level. 2.2. On oblasts level at least 2. 2.3. At least 120 entrepreneurs trained and consulted, of which at least 20% are female. 2.5. At least 50% of clients are satisfied and paying for the services. 2.6. At least 3 recommendations submitted. 2.7. At least 9 of participating SMEs increased their export turnover by 10% 3.1.1. At least 7 business ideas supported by BCF in 2015. 3.1.2. At least 40 jobs created, 30% for female in 2015. 3.1.3. At least 4 enterprises in 2015. 3.1.4. At least 10% p.a. 3.1.5. At least 5% increase p.a.
